q: What is a 'Work Loop' in Fiber?

q: Why Lanes instead of expiration times?
o: Lanes allow representing multiple overlapping priorities and disjoint sets of work more efficiently (CPU vs IO bound)

q: What is 'Double Buffering' in Fiber tree?
o: React maintains two trees: 'Current' (on screen) and 'WorkInProgress' (being built). Commit swamps them.
Seamless updates. If Wip tree throws error or is interrupted, Current tree remains valid on screen (no corrupted UI).
Optimization where React accumulates fibers with side-effects into a linear list to iterate quickly during Commit phase (skipping tree traversal)
If called inside render, it creates a new ref object every time (doesn't hold value). Use `useRef` hook for persistence.
No, mutating current does not trigger re-render. Good for perf when UI update isn't needed.
Poor if value updates often. All 1000 re-render. Use `memo` in consumers or state management library to optimize subscriptions.
`useContextSelector(Context, v => v.a)` - allows component to re-render only if selected part changes
When you need to measure DOM immediately after specific state update (e.g. maintaining scroll position on new message)
Low-level profiling tool (chrome://tracing) showing detailed browser/V8/GPU activity. React emits marks here.
Yes, if browser supports it (native priority scheduling API), React uses it for better coordination with other main thread work
Browser API allowing JS loop to check if user has clicked/typed, enabling early yield (responsiveness)
When V8 abandons optimized machine code (TurboFan) and falls back to interpreter (Ignition) because assumptions (types/shapes) failed
Calling same function with objects of different shapes (hidden classes). V8 can handle mono/morphic, but mega-morphic (many shapes) is slow.
Closures (hooks) create new function instances per render (memory pressure). Classes reuse prototype methods (less memory). But engines optimize closures well now.

q: Is 'Inline Caching' relevant to React props?
o: Yes, keeping prop object shape consistent (same keys, same order) helps engine optimize property access
Changing class, inline style, or matching complex selectors. Occurs before Layout.
Browser matches selectors right-to-left. Deep nesting `.a .b .c` or universal `*` can be expensive in huge DOMs.
Creating too many GPU layers (e.g. `will-change` on every item) consuming all video memory and causing crashes/slowness
Steady high memory usage (not a leak, but inefficient retention). Causes frequent GC pauses.
Minor collects young objects (cheap/fast). Major collects old objects (expensive/stop-the-world).

q: How to avoid Major GC pauses in animation?
o: Avoid allocating objects inside the animation loop (reuse objects)
API to estimate memory usage of web page (controlled by COOP/COEP headers)
If bundler can't prove a module import has no side effects, it includes it even if unused. Add `sideEffects: false` to help.
Comment `/*#__PURE__*/` telling minifier function call is safe to remove if return value unused
Good for dev correctness, but adds runtime overhead. Don't use in hot paths in prod.
JS engine optimized for React Native (fast startup, bytecode precompilation)
Smaller than source, faster to parse/execute (skips parsing step on device)
Disk cache of compiled bytecode for frequently used scripts
Layout containment isolates geometry. Paint containment isolates pixels (clipping).
Like `display: none` but caches rendering state (fast to reshow)

q: What is using `key` for state reset?
o: Changing the key of a component forces React to unmount and remount it (resetting state completely). Useful pattern.
Yes, compared to update. But cheaper than manual complex reset logic sometimes. Use judiciously.
Component rendered but output (DOM) didn't change (gray in some visualizations)
No, it iterates. You usually `cloneElement` inside the map callback to modify props.
Creates new element object. Not free, but usually negligible. Less efficient than passing props directly if possible.
Defining component outside usage scope (or parent) to prevent re-creation on every render

q: Impact of defining component A inside component B?
o: A is re-defined every render of B. React sees it as a NEW component type. Full unmount/remount of A every time. Terrible perf.
`const ref = useRef(null); if (ref.current === null) ref.current = heavy();`

q: Why use lazy init for refs?
o: If you pass `heavy()` to `useRef(heavy())`, it runs every render (value discarded after first).
Optimizing before measuring bottlenecks (root of all evil). Often complicates code without benefit.
Keep frame budget under 10ms (leaving 6ms for browser overhead) for 60fps
Checks if object is a React element (safe to render). Fast O(1).
createRoot for CSR (empty container). hydrateRoot for SSR (container has HTML).
Hydration mismatch error. Use `suppressHydrationWarning` on element if difference is inevitable (timestamps).
Negligible. It just silence the warning. Content is patched up.
Verifies that children has exactly one child (throws otherwise) and returns it. Useful for HOCs expecting single child.
Returns opaque data structure of children as flat array with keys assigned to each child
Yes, it prefixes them to ensure uniqueness in the flattened array

q: What is 'Render Phase' vs 'Commit Phase' errors?
o: Render phase errors are caught by Error Boundaries (getDerivedStateFromError). Commit phase errors are also caught.

q: Are async errors caught by Error Boundary?
o: No, not in React. Need `window.onerror` or `unhandledrejection` listeners.
`setInterval` not cleared in `useEffect` cleanup runs forever, trying to `setState` on unmounted component
Child component selecting data from store that has been removed by parent action, but child renders before parent unmounts it.
Using `useSyncExternalStore` (React 18) or top-down subscription logic ensures consistency
Function checking if object keys and values (strict equality) match. Skips deep objects.
Not exported publicly easily (internal uses). Redux exports it. React.memo uses it for props.
Use for large integers. Be efficient with serializing (JSON doesn't support it natively).
V8 engine mechanism. Adding props in different order `a,b` vs `b,a` creates different hidden classes, slowing access.
V8 stores small integers directly in pointer value (tagged). Floating point needs allocation. Prefer integers for loops.
Set of interactions (e.g. clicks) being traced during this commit
Found to be flawed/too overhead. Superseded by `scheduler` profiling.
`performance.mark('name')` creates a timestamp in browser timeline
Yes in Dev mode (visible in Performance tab under User Timing), e.g. ` App [mount]`
Isolates a subtree from rest of page (layout, style, paint). Allows browser to optimize heavily.
On container of complex widget (map, feed) to prevent its changes from causing global reflow
Using GPU to paint tiles of the page (faster than CPU for bitmaps)
No, consumes memory for a new backing store (layer). Use sparingly.
Browser taking painted layers and putting them together on screen (GPU accelerated, very fast)
Triggers layout (reflow) of element and children/neighbors every frame
First, Last, Invert, Play. Calculate positions, set transform to facilitate smooth transition using compositor.
Yes, if using ES module imports. But giant theme objects can sometimes prevent full optimization.
Tool showing how much bytes of loaded JS/CSS were actually executed. Helps identify unused code.
Uses Proxies. Slightly slower than raw manual spreading, but negligible for most apps compared to safety/dev speed.
Creates a proxy that can be disabled (garbage collected properly of handler). Advanced memory management.
Generally yes for frequent additions/removals of keys. Map preserves insertion order too.
Throttle: max X times per second. Debounce: wait X ms after last event. Debounce implies delay.
Scroll events, Drag events (update consistently but not every pixel)
Library to batch DOM reads/writes to prevent layout thrashing (used internally by some UI libs)
Yes, blocking main thread on I/O. Avoid for large data or hot paths.
Yes, sent with EVERY HTTP request to same domain. Keep small to avoid bandwidth overhead.
Serving assets from multiple subdomains (static1, static2) to bypass browser connection limit per domain. Obsolete in HTTP/2.

q: Why is Domain Sharding bad in HTTP/2?
o: Prevents HPACK header compression efficiency and multiplexing benefits. Single domain is better.

q: What is `priority` prop in Next.js Image?
o: Preloads image (High Priority) and disables lazy loading. Use for LCP element.

q: What is `sizes` prop in Image optimization?
o: Hints browser about display size of image at different breakpoints so it picks correct `srcset` variant
Next-gen image format, usually better compression than WebP. Supported in modern browsers.
Fast (bypass React diffing for children), but risky (XSS).
Inline scripts block HTML parser until executed. Put at bottom or use differ/async.
Accessing local var is faster than global (climbing scope chain). Minifiers help by aliasing globals.
Temporal Dead Zone. Accessing `let`/`const` before declaration throws error. Engine checks this cost.
Switch usually faster for many cases (jump table optimization). If-else is linear.
Engine reusing stack frame for recursive function calls properly. Safari supports it. V8 dropped it.
Can cause stack overflow if deep. Iteration is safer/faster usually.

q: What is `React.useEffect` empty deps `[]` vs no deps?
o: `[]` runs once (mount). No deps runs every render.
Equivalent timing (synchronous after mutation). `useEffect` is deferred (new in Hooks).
No, it compiles away to Fragment or similar. No double invoke in prod.
